title: 108_hr5403
content: The Act titled "Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004" aims to improve the quality of long term care in skilled nursing facilities under Medicare. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 introduces a new subsection requiring skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures separately by staff level for wages and benefits. The Secretary will redesign cost reports to meet this requirement. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 mandates skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures by staff level for wages and benefits. The Secretary will redesign cost reports to comply with this requirement and develop quality measures in consultation with experts and stakeholders. These measures may include process and structural indicators like direct care staffing and new technologies. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 mandates skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures by staff level for wages and benefits. Quality measures for new technologies in data collection systems should be valid, reliable, and minimize provider burden. Special provisions for small skilled nursing facilities are included in the quality measures. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures by staff level. Quality performance measures are developed and posted on the Secretary's website for the Medicare program. Payment rates are maintained at fiscal year 2005 levels as a minimum, with adjustments made for quality performance. The Secretary will develop and test methods to link payment rates to quality in consultation with various stakeholders. These methods will tie a portion of provider payments to quality indicators, with a focus on facilities that provide higher levels of direct care staffing. The Secretary will develop and test methods to link payment rates to quality in consultation with stakeholders, focusing on facilities providing more direct care staffing. Deadline for developing quality measures and payment methods is 54 months after enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on financing options for quality nursing facility care, including Medicaid adequacy, Medicare cross-subsidization, industry margins, trends impact, demographic changes, and payment solutions for nursing facility services. Options for financing quality long term care, including nursing home care, will be reported annually to Congress by the Secretary, with a final report due within 5 years. This report will include the study results and recommendations for changes to the Medicare payment system for extended care services. This report will include study results and recommendations for changes to the Medicare payment system for extended care services, as well as an analysis of alternative approaches to addressing other identified issues.
